Yes the Doritos Locos Tacos tastes great. But the decision made by my local Taco Bell to limit all its non supervisory workers to less than 28 hours per week to avoid paying for medical benefits for their frontline workers has left a bad taste in my mouth that would spoil any meal from any Taco Bell, whether it be in Alexandria, LA, or any other franchise location.

Just one more reason to avoid fast food that tastes good but is bad for everyone's health and well-being.
Hey, I'm irish but that doesn't make an expert on corned beef and cabbage. Just sayin', ken.

I would have liked to have heard the food science behind the dorito loco taco. Instead, I got something like "food theory" behind this analysis. I can't say it was that rigorous, either. One could almost say that it was as vapid and silly as the foodstuff it skewered. A vapid analysis of a vapid foodstuff.

In your mind. In your opinion. Those are the qualifiers here.

You're correct that many of the foods eaten are lacking in nutrients and are not a healthy addition to diet but your dissertation is nothing more than typical internet ranting. You've sidestepped the topic of the article to spew dogma that is filled with logical fallacies, uncited and unsupported claims.

It's a shame, your rambling diatribe will likely garner more attention and support than anything that actually adds to the quality of a discussion.

Kudos on contributing to the deterioration of internet discussion.

"Hang out with their patients"?

It takes time to explain and teach about health and disease, discuss prevention, diet, exercise, vaccinations, smoking, alcohol, HIV, depression, domestic violence, fall risk at home, how to take medications, fill out forms, refills, find an interpreter when needed, and the list goes on and on. It takes more time when someone has low literacy or is hearing or visually impaired.

"Who does it benefit when they practice the way they feel it ought to be done?" Everyone, patient and doctor. When there is not good prevention and education, a society will pay for it in the long-run. Not all, but most expensive hospital inpatient and ICU admissions could have been prevented.
If you can vote, please keep doing so; maybe we'll take back civilized discourse someday.

I immigrated to the United States in the mid eighties from West Africa and the thing that I fell in love with the political system and the way legislators treated each other  respectively, but now when I look at the political spectrum I see nothing but contempt.
That's some potent Merlot!

Thursday, Oct 3, 2013. House Speaker John Boehner makes a short speech to the nation:  "My fellow Americans, I have concluded that closing down the government was a terrible idea and that refusing to raise the debt ceiling in order to ensure that the nation's outstanding bills be paid would constitute an even worse one.  Hence, I have agreed to send a continuing resolution to the floor of the House at this time, stripping from it any and all demands relative to the Affordable Care Act.  I am asking that all of my Republican colleagues in the House, as well as all Democrats, vote for passage of this resolution, despite the fact that I continue to have serious reservations about the Affordable Care Act and continue to believe that it should never have been passed or signed into law.  I remain convinced that the ACA will prove to be a complete and utter failure and that my party will be justifiably rewarded at the polls on Election Day in 2014 for having opposed its passage.  At which point, we will try again to rescind the law or, at the very least, to amend and improve it to the point where it will serve the needs of all Americans- rich and poor, black and white, healthy and unhealthy.  Furthermore, if it develops that I have erred in my estimation of the benefits of the Act, I will without hesitation acknowledge my poor judgment and refrain from once more running for reelection to the House. I bid you all a good day."  And then he wakes up.

The one year delay would be no different than the three minutes between rounds in a boxing match. The Republicans stated goal is to destroy the ACA, without any real alternative being offered. They would just use the year for further attempts to make the ACA fail. If their goal had any good intentions associated with it, it might be a little different.
As a Physician, I know that change in healthcare delivery is going to occur. The last thing we need is to have the rules change every few months. It is hard enough to implement as it is. Changes this big are always chaotic, and if the Republicans offered a serious plan, it would be no different, i.e., it would still be chaotic. It is easy to offer one page summary plans for healthcare reform. The devil is in the details. Any Republican plan is going to be similar to the ACA by the time it is fleshed out to the point where it can be enacted.
Besides, the ACA is similar enough to Romneycare and previous proposals by Republican think tanks that I can't believe that a Republican plan would be all that different. Most Republican behavior now is simply anti-Obama. Republican leaders stated long ago that their goal was to make Obama fail, even if it hurt the American people. They have stuck to their word.

Delaying the individual mandate would be tricky because they really do need to apply force to get people to enroll. OTH, it would also allow people to see what they are getting into and give the exchanges time to actually work.

There's so much confusion at this point not because people are "ignorant" but because it's a lot to absorb and the information just hasn't been available at the level of detail necessary for people to actually evaluate it. Not everyone has been willing to take the Administration's word for it.

The unknowns have loomed large. It's been one long battle of over-promising and hypothetical benefits vs. doom-and-gloom disaster. People have lined up on both sides before actually seeing it. Projection has morphed into reality.

Now that people are able to see it, they may just need more time to absorb the change.

Andrea - Can you tell us what force is being applied and by whom to the millions of people who have already just since yesterday signed up or are checking out what their alternatives are so that they can do so as soon as possible?

This article is a joke.  Of course this is pure politics, and both sides are to blame.  The CR passed by the House would NOT destroy Obamacare, as every media outlet seems to imply.  It would 1) delay the individual mandate for one year, same as the delay for the corporate mandate and 2) remove the exemption for Congress and its staff. There is no good reason for Obama to object to these ideas. Obama delayed the corporate mandate!  Why should individuals not be given the same option?  As for Congress and its staff getting exemptions, why would any voter object to this?  Who cares if scores of staffers quit because their insurance costs go up?  That would be their choice, and giving them special treatment is the height of government cronyism.  It's pathetic how little people understand the situation, especially the editorial board of the Times and the vast majority of people responding to this article.

He's a bought and paid for empty suit, a stand in for the right wing billionaires who want to strip away the last vestiges of free elections from this society.
It's not enough that individuals and corporations can already give unlimited amounts to Pacs, now they want to mainline it right to the candidate of their choosing, creating a government more accountable to the wealthy in this country than they already are.

God help us.

That is exactly what the research on Congress finds: donors who give more money to congressional campaigns get to spend more time with the members of Congress than do small donors or people who don't give at all.  If you want to increase the power of the rich, get rid of the donation limits.

Actually, the nonpartisan research on the "mainstream media" finds that it does not have a consistent ideological or party bias.  We do find instances in which a given liberal or Democrat gets more positive coverage than a given conservative or Republican, but we also find the opposite pattern.  The people funding the organization you mention are mostly the major corporations of our country--they pay for the advertising.  If you think the leaders of our major corporations are a bunch of ultra-leftist Democrats, you need to pay more attention.  In addition, guess which party controlled the White House when the US abandoned the Fairness Doctrine and the Equal Time Rule.  It wasn't the excreble, evil, warped, ultraleftist Democratic villains.  Sorry.

The Supreme Court already ruled that spending limits are not constitutional except if a candidate accepts public funding (and maybe not even then).  Certainly Mr. Bopp and his allies wouldn't support public funding of congressional campaigns.

The problem with the transparency remedy is that very few reporters and even fewer citizens ever look at campaign finance reports.  Also, some groups create financial arms with vague or misleading titles (Citizens for a Fair Tax System, Citizens for Homeland Security, etc.), and people would need to track down who or what finances those groups in order to understand the campaign finance reports of candidates.  Most people won't make the effort--and wouldn't need to if we had a fair funding system.

I am not sure whether to laugh or cry when the "strict constructionists" on the Supreme Court and elsewhere argue that money, especially corporate money, is speech.

Our Founding Fathers (and Mothers also) would have laughed at that equation. It is entirely a creation of the Supreme Court.

The beginning of the process which lead to this dates back to the 19th century, when the Court decided on its own that state issued permitted creations -- which are what corporations are -- were Federally protected persons. (This back when Blacks were still 3/5 of a person.) That concept grew and grew under successive Courts, culminating in the Citizens United decision.

Interestingly, the Court never seems to note the restrictions it has placed on real people, the you-can't-yell-fire-in-a-crowded-theater rule. Even if corporations could be justified as "persons", by that rule one could reasonably conclude that individuals corrupting the political process with mega-contributions was yelling fire in the theater of our vulnerable political process.

Ah, yes, but money does talk, and therein lies the problem.

barry:

I was born and grew up on Puget Sound. A few centuries ago, it seems.

You miss the primary discontinuity that makes the smaller discontinuity of bad internment policies inevitable: war; and, particularly now with wars that don't present uniforms or are even really waged by states. For people of the west, that have largely evolved beyond its need, except as wary and unwilling stabilizing hand to societies that still are trying to find themselves, war is a massive discontinuity that rational forms of governance don't manage well.

The trick, rather than mastering its oddities and contradictions, is to wage it successfully and rarely, and not allow its intrusions to dominate how we govern ourselves normally.

Richard:  Your second post, especially the last sentence is a good thought.  However, what has happened has been the opposite.  The "USAPATRIOTACT" (check the name) and its companions have done a lot of damage to this country's ideals.

I'm reminded of Richard Nixon's rather earthier expression.

We have a precipitating event to a great calamity that occurs about once in a century -- for FDR, it was Pearl Harbor, for Dubya it was 9/11 -- and we fashion emergency protocols to address the emergency in ways that make as much sense as possible at the time to leaders who are quite consumed dealing with more pressing aspects of the response. Those protocols, and how they fit within our framework of justice, typically are awkward.

Yet, we may not confront another such emergency for a century -- not an unreasonable expectation, with a Patriot Act, a Homeland Security Dept. and facilitated means for foreign intelligence and domestic police organizations to communicate, as well as NSA and its Salt Lake City bunker.

How pressing is it likely to be regarded to fit emergency protocols into the mature framework? To the professional, it might be pressing whether a specific act is a fit charge or not for a military commission to try. But most of us expect that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and his fellow-travelers either will hang or be breaking rocks for the remainder of their lives, one way or another -- and America would be mightily unhappy if such were not the case.

Most wouldn't see this issue as immensely important. The next president who needs to deal with such actions will direct military commissions to act as he finds needful, and the very infrequency and uniqueness of such need will not threaten the mature framework.

My father was a printer. When I was about 10, he started working for J.J. Little and Ives Company, book printers in New York City. As I write this, I'm looking at a first edition of Norman Mailer's "The Naked and the Dead," which my father brought home from work. He would bring many books home over the years. When I first read Mailer, I felt bold and naughty because of that title and read it in secret, even though I didn't understand many parts of it.
Wonderful! You made me laugh Karen.

I second this. I innocently came across this book in my parents' library when I was around 15. I kept sneaking downstairs to read parts of it and then eventually spirited it away to my closet. . . .where it remains hidden 15 years later.

Although not the first, but the one that makes me chuckle thinking about the context is having read Nancy Friday's My Secret Garden, a book of female sexual fantasies at age 15 while staying at the International Girl Scout House in Switzerland. Somehow I don't think the parents back home envisioned that book be passed secretly from girl to girl staying there!

Someone discovered that there was a huge profit to be made in Medicine, and it wasn't the doctors.  CEO's of medical systems and insurance  companies now routinely make over $5 million per year.  My "non-profit" medial center makes hundreds of millions of dollars per year, and nearly 30 administrators make > $1 million per year.  The average non-surgeon salary is less than one fifth of that.  Yet my productivity requirement keeps going up and they're firing my staff because of "budget cuts".  I'm old enough to remember having time to talk to patients, but too young to retire (and still paying off my medical school loans)  I'm starting to look at other options.  I'm tired of running as fast as I can to stay in place.

Whoa. Thanks for the memories! Also read (parts of) this at around 10 or 11. Found it stashed in my sister's kitchen pantry - she must have put it there for my visit - which I came to consider the best library in town, I also remember finding and reading M*A*S*H*, though I can't see why she thought that had to be kept hidden.

The Fear of Flying by Erica Jong. I was too young to understand her brand of humor and take on relationships. I just wanted to skip to the naughty bits, seeing as I was hitting puberty pretty hard (so to speak).
